segment.source: Create a Microsoft Passport login service
segment.target: Create a Microsoft Passport login service

segment.source: This is Part 2 of a complete walkthrough on how to use Microsoft Passport as an alternative to traditional username and password authentication systems in Windows 10 UWP (Universal Windows platform) apps.
segment.target: This is Part 2 of a complete walkthrough on how to use Microsoft Passport as an alternative to traditional username and password authentication systems in Windows 10 UWP (Universal Windows platform) apps.

segment.source: Create a Microsoft Passport login service
segment.target: Create a Microsoft Passport login service

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: \[Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
segment.target: \[Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

segment.source: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\]
segment.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\]

segment.source: This is Part 2 of a complete walkthrough on how to use Microsoft Passport as an alternative to traditional username and password authentication systems in Windows 10 UWP (Universal Windows platform) apps.
segment.target: This is Part 2 of a complete walkthrough on how to use Microsoft Passport as an alternative to traditional username and password authentication systems in Windows 10 UWP (Universal Windows platform) apps.

segment.source: This article picks up where Part 1, Microsoft Passport login app, left off and extends the functionality to demonstrate how you can integrate Microsoft Passport into your existing application.
segment.target: This article picks up where Part 1, Microsoft Passport login app, left off and extends the functionality to demonstrate how you can integrate Microsoft Passport into your existing application.

segment.source: In order to build this project, you'll need some experience with C#, and XAML.
segment.target: In order to build this project, you'll need some experience with C#, and XAML.

segment.source: You'll also need to be using Visual Studio 2015 (Community Edition or greater) on a Windows 10 machine.
segment.target: You'll also need to be using Visual Studio 2015 (Community Edition or greater) on a Windows 10 machine.

segment.source: Exercise 1: Server Side Logic
segment.target: Exercise 1: Server Side Logic

segment.source: In this exercise you will be starting with the Passport application built in the first lab and creating a local mock server and database.
segment.target: In this exercise you will be starting with the Passport application built in the first lab and creating a local mock server and database.

segment.source: This hands on lab is designed to teach how Microsoft Passport could be integrated into an existing system.
segment.target: This hands on lab is designed to teach how Microsoft Passport could be integrated into an existing system.

segment.source: By using a mock server and mock database a lot of unrelated setup is eliminated.
segment.target: By using a mock server and mock database a lot of unrelated setup is eliminated.

segment.source: In your own applications you will need to replace the mock objects with the real services and databases.
segment.target: In your own applications you will need to replace the mock objects with the real services and databases.

segment.source: To begin, open up the PassportLogin solution from the first Passport Hands On Lab.
segment.target: To begin, open up the PassportLogin solution from the first Passport Hands On Lab.

segment.source: You will start by implementing the mock server and mock database.
segment.target: You will start by implementing the mock server and mock database.

segment.source: Create a new folder called "AuthService".
segment.target: Create a new folder called "AuthService".

segment.source: In solution explorer right click on the solution "PassportLogin (Universal Windows)" and select Add > New Folder.
segment.target: In solution explorer right click on the solution "PassportLogin (Universal Windows)" and select Add > New Folder.

segment.source: Create UserAccount and PassportDevices classes that will act as models for data to be saved in the mock database.
segment.target: Create UserAccount and PassportDevices classes that will act as models for data to be saved in the mock database.

segment.source: The UserAccount will be similar to the user model implemented on a traditional authentication server.
segment.target: The UserAccount will be similar to the user model implemented on a traditional authentication server.

segment.source: Right click on the AuthService folder and add a new class called "UserAccount.cs."
segment.target: Right click on the AuthService folder and add a new class called "UserAccount.cs."

segment.source: Change the class definition to be public and then add the following public properties.
segment.target: Change the class definition to be public and then add the following public properties.

segment.source: You will need the following reference.
segment.target: You will need the following reference.

segment.source: You may have noticed the commented out list of PassportDevices.
segment.target: You may have noticed the commented out list of PassportDevices.

segment.source: This is a modification you will need to make to an existing user model in your current implementation.
segment.target: This is a modification you will need to make to an existing user model in your current implementation.

segment.source: The list of PassportDevices will contain a deviceID, the public key made from Microsoft Passport, and a KeyCredentialAttestationResult.
segment.target: The list of PassportDevices will contain a deviceID, the public key made from Microsoft Passport, and a KeyCredentialAttestationResult.

segment.source: For this hands on lab you will need to implement the keyAttestationResult as they are only provided by Microsoft Passport on devices that have a TPM (Trusted Platform Modules) chip.
segment.target: For this hands on lab you will need to implement the keyAttestationResult as they are only provided by Microsoft Passport on devices that have a TPM (Trusted Platform Modules) chip.

segment.source: The KeyCredentialAttestationResult is a combination of multiple properties and would need to be split in order to save and load them with a database.
segment.target: The KeyCredentialAttestationResult is a combination of multiple properties and would need to be split in order to save and load them with a database.

segment.source: Create a new class in the AuthService folder called "PassportDevice.cs".
segment.target: Create a new class in the AuthService folder called "PassportDevice.cs".

segment.source: This is the model for the passport devices as discussed above.
segment.target: This is the model for the passport devices as discussed above.

segment.source: Change the class definition to be public and add the following properties.
segment.target: Change the class definition to be public and add the following properties.

segment.source: Return to in UserAccount.cs and uncomment the list of Passport devices.
segment.target: Return to in UserAccount.cs and uncomment the list of Passport devices.

segment.source: With the model for the UserAccount and the PassportDevice created, you need to create another new class in the AuthService that will act as the mock database.
segment.target: With the model for the UserAccount and the PassportDevice created, you need to create another new class in the AuthService that will act as the mock database.

segment.source: As this is a mock database from where you will be saving and loading a list of user accounts locally.
segment.target: As this is a mock database from where you will be saving and loading a list of user accounts locally.

segment.source: In the real world this would be your database implementation.
segment.target: In the real world this would be your database implementation.

segment.source: Create a new class in AuthService called "MockStore.cs".
segment.target: Create a new class in AuthService called "MockStore.cs".

segment.source: Change the class definition to public.
segment.target: Change the class definition to public.

segment.source: As the mock store will save and load a list of user accounts locally you can implement the logic to save and load that list using an XmlSerializer.
segment.target: As the mock store will save and load a list of user accounts locally you can implement the logic to save and load that list using an XmlSerializer.

segment.source: You will also need to remember the filename and save location.
segment.target: You will also need to remember the filename and save location.

segment.source: In MockStore.cs implement the following:
segment.target: In MockStore.cs implement the following:

segment.source: In the load method you may have noticed that an InitializeSampleUserAccounts method was commented out.
segment.target: In the load method you may have noticed that an InitializeSampleUserAccounts method was commented out.

segment.source: You will need to create this method in the MockStore.cs.
segment.target: You will need to create this method in the MockStore.cs.

segment.source: This method will populate the user accounts list so that a login can take place.
segment.target: This method will populate the user accounts list so that a login can take place.

segment.source: In the real world the user database would already be populated.
segment.target: In the real world the user database would already be populated.

segment.source: In this step you will also be creating a constructor that will initialise the user list and call load.
segment.target: In this step you will also be creating a constructor that will initialise the user list and call load.

segment.source: Now that the InitalizeSampleUserAccounts method exists uncomment the method call in the LoadAccountListAsync method.
segment.target: Now that the InitalizeSampleUserAccounts method exists uncomment the method call in the LoadAccountListAsync method.

segment.source: The user accounts list in mock store can now be saved and loaded.
segment.target: The user accounts list in mock store can now be saved and loaded.

segment.source: Other parts of the application will need to have access to this list so there will need to be some methods to retrieve this data.
segment.target: Other parts of the application will need to have access to this list so there will need to be some methods to retrieve this data.

segment.source: Underneath the InitializeSampleUserAccounts method, add the following get methods.
segment.target: Underneath the InitializeSampleUserAccounts method, add the following get methods.

segment.source: They will allow you to get a userid, a single user, a list of users for a specific Passport device, and also get the public key for the user on a specific device.
segment.target: They will allow you to get a userid, a single user, a list of users for a specific Passport device, and also get the public key for the user on a specific device.

segment.source: The next methods to implement will handle simple operations to add account, remove account, and also remove device.
segment.target: The next methods to implement will handle simple operations to add account, remove account, and also remove device.

segment.source: Remove device is needed as Microsoft Passport is device specific.
segment.target: Remove device is needed as Microsoft Passport is device specific.

segment.source: For each device to which you log in, a new public and private key pair will be created by Microsoft Passport.
segment.target: For each device to which you log in, a new public and private key pair will be created by Microsoft Passport.

segment.source: It is like having a different password for each device you sign in on, the only thing is you don’t need to remember all those passwords the server does.
segment.target: It is like having a different password for each device you sign in on, the only thing is you don’t need to remember all those passwords the server does.

segment.source: Add the following methods into the MockStore.cs
segment.target: Add the following methods into the MockStore.cs

segment.source: In the MockStore class add a method that will add Passport related information to an existing UserAccount.
segment.target: In the MockStore class add a method that will add Passport related information to an existing UserAccount.

segment.source: This method will be called PassportUpdateDetails and will take parameters to identify the user, and the Passport details.
segment.target: This method will be called PassportUpdateDetails and will take parameters to identify the user, and the Passport details.

segment.source: The KeyAttestationResult has been commented out when creating a PassportDevice, in a real world application you would require this.
segment.target: The KeyAttestationResult has been commented out when creating a PassportDevice, in a real world application you would require this.

segment.source: The MockStore class is now complete, as this represents the database it should be considered private.
segment.target: The MockStore class is now complete, as this represents the database it should be considered private.

segment.source: In order to access the MockStore an AuthService class is needed to manipulate the database data.
segment.target: In order to access the MockStore an AuthService class is needed to manipulate the database data.

segment.source: In the AuthService folder create a new class called "AuthService.cs".
segment.target: In the AuthService folder create a new class called "AuthService.cs".

segment.source: Change the class definition to public and add a singleton instance pattern to make sure only one instance is ever created.
segment.target: Change the class definition to public and add a singleton instance pattern to make sure only one instance is ever created.

segment.source: The AuthService class will need to create an instance of the MockStore class and provide access to the properties of the MockStore object.
segment.target: The AuthService class will need to create an instance of the MockStore class and provide access to the properties of the MockStore object.

segment.source: You need methods in the AuthService class to access add, remove, and update passport details methods in the MockStore object.
segment.target: You need methods in the AuthService class to access add, remove, and update passport details methods in the MockStore object.

segment.source: At the end of the AuthService class file add the following methods.
segment.target: At the end of the AuthService class file add the following methods.

segment.source: The AuthService class will need to provide a method to validate credentials.
segment.target: The AuthService class will need to provide a method to validate credentials.

segment.source: This method will take a username and password and make sure that account exists and the password is valid.
segment.target: This method will take a username and password and make sure that account exists and the password is valid.

segment.source: An existing system would have an equivalent method to this that checks the user is authorized.
segment.target: An existing system would have an equivalent method to this that checks the user is authorized.

segment.source: Add the following ValidateCredentials to the AuthService.cs file.
segment.target: Add the following ValidateCredentials to the AuthService.cs file.

segment.source: The AuthService class needs a request challenge method that will return a challenge to the client to validate the user is who they claim to be.
segment.target: The AuthService class needs a request challenge method that will return a challenge to the client to validate the user is who they claim to be.

segment.source: Then a method is needed in the AuthService class to receive the signed challenge back from the client.
segment.target: Then a method is needed in the AuthService class to receive the signed challenge back from the client.

segment.source: For this hands on lab the method of how you determine if the signed challenge has been completed has been left incomplete.
segment.target: For this hands on lab the method of how you determine if the signed challenge has been completed has been left incomplete.

segment.source: Every implementation of Microsoft Passport into an existing authentication system will be slightly different.
segment.target: Every implementation of Microsoft Passport into an existing authentication system will be slightly different.

segment.source: The public key stored on the server needs to match with the result the client returned to the server.
segment.target: The public key stored on the server needs to match with the result the client returned to the server.

segment.source: Add these two methods to AuthService.cs.
segment.target: Add these two methods to AuthService.cs.

segment.source: Exercise 2: Client Side Logic
segment.target: Exercise 2: Client Side Logic

segment.source: In this exercise you will be changing the client side views and helper classes from the first lab to use the AuthService class.
segment.target: In this exercise you will be changing the client side views and helper classes from the first lab to use the AuthService class.

segment.source: In the real world the AuthService would be the authentication server and you would need to use Web API’s to send and receive data from the server.
segment.target: In the real world the AuthService would be the authentication server and you would need to use Web API’s to send and receive data from the server.

segment.source: For this hands on lab client and server are all local to keep things simple.
segment.target: For this hands on lab client and server are all local to keep things simple.

segment.source: The objective is to learn how to use the Microsoft Passport APIs.
segment.target: The objective is to learn how to use the Microsoft Passport APIs.

segment.source: In the MainPage.xaml.cs you can remove the AccountHelper.LoadAccountListAsync method call in the loaded method as the AuthService class creates an instance of the MockStore which loads the accounts list.
segment.target: In the MainPage.xaml.cs you can remove the AccountHelper.LoadAccountListAsync method call in the loaded method as the AuthService class creates an instance of the MockStore which loads the accounts list.

segment.source: The loaded method should now look like below.
segment.target: The loaded method should now look like below.

segment.source: Note the async method definition is removed as nothing is being awaiting.
segment.target: Note the async method definition is removed as nothing is being awaiting.

segment.source: Update the Login page interface to require a passport be entered.
segment.target: Update the Login page interface to require a passport be entered.

segment.source: This hands on lab demonstrates how an existing system could be migrated to use Microsoft Passport and existing accounts will have a username and a password.
segment.target: This hands on lab demonstrates how an existing system could be migrated to use Microsoft Passport and existing accounts will have a username and a password.

segment.source: Also update the explanation at the bottom of the XAML to include the default password.
segment.target: Also update the explanation at the bottom of the XAML to include the default password.

segment.source: Update the following XAML in Login.xaml
segment.target: Update the following XAML in Login.xaml

segment.source: In the Login class code behind you will need to change the Account private variable at the top of the class to be a UserAccount.
segment.target: In the Login class code behind you will need to change the Account private variable at the top of the class to be a UserAccount.

segment.source: Change the OnNavigateTo event to cast the type to be a UserAccount.
segment.target: Change the OnNavigateTo event to cast the type to be a UserAccount.

segment.source: You will need the following reference.
segment.target: You will need the following reference.

segment.source: As the Login page is using a UserAccount object instead of the previous Account object the MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs will need to be updated to use a UserAccount as a parameter for some methods.
segment.target: As the Login page is using a UserAccount object instead of the previous Account object the MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs will need to be updated to use a UserAccount as a parameter for some methods.

segment.source: You will need to change the following parameters for the CreatePassportKeyAsync, RemovePassportAccountAsync and GetPassportAuthenticationMessageAsync methods.
segment.target: You will need to change the following parameters for the CreatePassportKeyAsync, RemovePassportAccountAsync and GetPassportAuthenticationMessageAsync methods.

segment.source: As the UserAccount class has a Guid for a UserId you will start using the Id in more places to be more specific.
segment.target: As the UserAccount class has a Guid for a UserId you will start using the Id in more places to be more specific.

segment.source: The SignInPassport method in Login.xaml.cs file will need to be updated to use the AuthService instead of the AccountHelper.
segment.target: The SignInPassport method in Login.xaml.cs file will need to be updated to use the AuthService instead of the AccountHelper.

segment.source: Validation of credentials will happen through the AuthService.
segment.target: Validation of credentials will happen through the AuthService.

segment.source: For this hands on lab the only configured account is "sampleUsername".
segment.target: For this hands on lab the only configured account is "sampleUsername".

segment.source: This account is created in the InitializeSampleUserAccounts method in MockStore.cs.
segment.target: This account is created in the InitializeSampleUserAccounts method in MockStore.cs.

segment.source: Update the SignInPassport method in Login.xaml.cs now to reflect the code snippet below.
segment.target: Update the SignInPassport method in Login.xaml.cs now to reflect the code snippet below.

segment.source: As Microsoft Passport will create a different public and private key pair for each account on each device the Welcome page will need to display a list of registered devices for the logged in account, and allow each one to be forgotten.
segment.target: As Microsoft Passport will create a different public and private key pair for each account on each device the Welcome page will need to display a list of registered devices for the logged in account, and allow each one to be forgotten.

segment.source: In Welcome.xaml add in the following XAML underneath the ForgetButton.
segment.target: In Welcome.xaml add in the following XAML underneath the ForgetButton.

segment.source: This will implement a forget device button, an error text area and a list to display all devices.
segment.target: This will implement a forget device button, an error text area and a list to display all devices.

segment.source: In the Welcome.xaml.cs file you will need to change the private Account variable at the top of the class to be a private UserAccount variable.
segment.target: In the Welcome.xaml.cs file you will need to change the private Account variable at the top of the class to be a private UserAccount variable.

segment.source: Then update the OnNavigatedTo method to use the AuthService and retrieve information for the current account.
segment.target: Then update the OnNavigatedTo method to use the AuthService and retrieve information for the current account.

segment.source: When you have the account information you can set the itemsource of the list to display the devices.
segment.target: When you have the account information you can set the itemsource of the list to display the devices.

segment.source: You will need to add a reference to the AuthService namespace.
segment.target: You will need to add a reference to the AuthService namespace.

segment.source: As you will be using the AuthService when removing an account the reference to the AccountHelper in the Button\_Forget\_User\_Click method can be removed.
segment.target: As you will be using the AuthService when removing an account the reference to the AccountHelper in the Button\_Forget\_User\_Click method can be removed.

segment.source: The method should now look as below.
segment.target: The method should now look as below.

segment.source: The MicrosoftPassportHelper method is not using the AuthService to remove the account.
segment.target: The MicrosoftPassportHelper method is not using the AuthService to remove the account.

segment.source: You need to make a call to the AuthService and pass the userId.
segment.target: You need to make a call to the AuthService and pass the userId.

segment.source: Before you can finish implementing the Welcome page class, you need to create a method in MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs that will allow a device to be removed.
segment.target: Before you can finish implementing the Welcome page class, you need to create a method in MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs that will allow a device to be removed.

segment.source: Create a new method that will call PassportRemoveDevice in AuthService.
segment.target: Create a new method that will call PassportRemoveDevice in AuthService.

segment.source: In Welcome.xaml.cs implement the Forget Device click event.
segment.target: In Welcome.xaml.cs implement the Forget Device click event.

segment.source: This will use the selected device from the list of devices and use the passport helper to call remove device.
segment.target: This will use the selected device from the list of devices and use the passport helper to call remove device.

segment.source: The next page you will update is the UserSelection page.
segment.target: The next page you will update is the UserSelection page.

segment.source: The UserSelection page will need to use the AuthService to retrieve all user accounts for the current device.
segment.target: The UserSelection page will need to use the AuthService to retrieve all user accounts for the current device.

segment.source: Currently there is no way for you get a device id to pass to the AuthService so it can return user accounts for that device.
segment.target: Currently there is no way for you get a device id to pass to the AuthService so it can return user accounts for that device.

segment.source: In the Utils folder create a new class called "Helpers.cs".
segment.target: In the Utils folder create a new class called "Helpers.cs".

segment.source: Change the class definition to be public static and then add the following method that will allow you to retrieve the current device id.
segment.target: Change the class definition to be public static and then add the following method that will allow you to retrieve the current device id.

segment.source: In the UserSelection page class only the code behind needs to change, not the user interface.
segment.target: In the UserSelection page class only the code behind needs to change, not the user interface.

segment.source: In UserSelection.xaml.cs update the loaded method and the user selection method to use the UserAccount class instead of the Account class.
segment.target: In UserSelection.xaml.cs update the loaded method and the user selection method to use the UserAccount class instead of the Account class.

segment.source: You will also need to get all users for this device through the AuthService.
segment.target: You will also need to get all users for this device through the AuthService.

segment.source: The PassportRegister page needs to update the code behind, the user interface does not need changing.
segment.target: The PassportRegister page needs to update the code behind, the user interface does not need changing.

segment.source: In PassportRegister.xaml.cs remove the private Account variable at the top of the class as it is no longer needed.
segment.target: In PassportRegister.xaml.cs remove the private Account variable at the top of the class as it is no longer needed.

segment.source: Update the RegisterButton click event to use the AuthService.
segment.target: Update the RegisterButton click event to use the AuthService.

segment.source: This method will create a new UserAccount and then try and update its passport details.
segment.target: This method will create a new UserAccount and then try and update its passport details.

segment.source: If passport fails to create a passport key the account will be removed as the registration process failed.
segment.target: If passport fails to create a passport key the account will be removed as the registration process failed.

segment.source: Build and run the application (F5).
segment.target: Build and run the application (F5).

segment.source: Sign into the sample user account, with the credentials "sampleUsername" and "samplePassword".
segment.target: Sign into the sample user account, with the credentials "sampleUsername" and "samplePassword".

segment.source: On the welcome screen you may notice the Forget devices button is displayed but there are no devices.
segment.target: On the welcome screen you may notice the Forget devices button is displayed but there are no devices.

segment.source: When you are creating or migrating a user to work with Microsoft Passport the Passport information is not being pushed to the AuthService.
segment.target: When you are creating or migrating a user to work with Microsoft Passport the Passport information is not being pushed to the AuthService.

segment.source: To get the Passport information to the AuthService the MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs will need to be updated.
segment.target: To get the Passport information to the AuthService the MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs will need to be updated.

segment.source: In the CreatePassportKeyAsync method, instead of only returning true in the case that it is successful, you will need to call a new method which will try to get the KeyAttestation.
segment.target: In the CreatePassportKeyAsync method, instead of only returning true in the case that it is successful, you will need to call a new method which will try to get the KeyAttestation.

segment.source: While this hands on lab is not recording this information in the AuthService you will learn how you would get it this information on the client side.
segment.target: While this hands on lab is not recording this information in the AuthService you will learn how you would get it this information on the client side.

segment.source: Update the CreatePassportKeyAsync method.
segment.target: Update the CreatePassportKeyAsync method.

segment.source: Create this GetKeyAttestationAsync method in MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs.
segment.target: Create this GetKeyAttestationAsync method in MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs.

segment.source: This method will demonstrate how to obtain all the necessary information that can be provided by Microsoft Passport for each account on a specific device.
segment.target: This method will demonstrate how to obtain all the necessary information that can be provided by Microsoft Passport for each account on a specific device.

segment.source: You may have noticed in the GetKeyAttestationAsync method that you just added the last line was commented out.
segment.target: You may have noticed in the GetKeyAttestationAsync method that you just added the last line was commented out.

segment.source: This last line will be a new method you create that will send all the Microsoft Passport information to the AuthService.
segment.target: This last line will be a new method you create that will send all the Microsoft Passport information to the AuthService.

segment.source: In the real world you would need to send this to an actual server with a Web API.
segment.target: In the real world you would need to send this to an actual server with a Web API.

segment.source: Uncomment the last line in the GetKeyAttestationAsync method so that the Microsoft Passport information is being sent to the AuthService.
segment.target: Uncomment the last line in the GetKeyAttestationAsync method so that the Microsoft Passport information is being sent to the AuthService.

segment.source: Build and run the application and sign in with the default credentials as before.
segment.target: Build and run the application and sign in with the default credentials as before.

segment.source: On the welcome screen you will now see that the device Id is displayed.
segment.target: On the welcome screen you will now see that the device Id is displayed.

segment.source: If you signed in on another device that would also be displayed here (if you had a cloud hosted auth service).
segment.target: If you signed in on another device that would also be displayed here (if you had a cloud hosted auth service).

segment.source: For this hands on lab the actual device Id is being displayed.
segment.target: For this hands on lab the actual device Id is being displayed.

segment.source: In a real implementation you would want to display a friendly name that a person could understand and use to determine each device.
segment.target: In a real implementation you would want to display a friendly name that a person could understand and use to determine each device.

segment.source: To complete this hands on lab you need a request and challenge for the user when they select from the user selection page and sign back in.
segment.target: To complete this hands on lab you need a request and challenge for the user when they select from the user selection page and sign back in.

segment.source: The AuthService has two methods that you created to request a challenge, one that uses a signed challenge.
segment.target: The AuthService has two methods that you created to request a challenge, one that uses a signed challenge.

segment.source: In MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs create a new method called "RequestSignAsync" This will request a challenge from the AuthService, locally sign that challenge using a Passport API and send the signed challenge to the AuthService.
segment.target: In MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs create a new method called "RequestSignAsync" This will request a challenge from the AuthService, locally sign that challenge using a Passport API and send the signed challenge to the AuthService.

segment.source: In this hands on lab the AuthService will receive the signed challenge and return true.
segment.target: In this hands on lab the AuthService will receive the signed challenge and return true.

segment.source: In an actual implementation you would need to implement a verification mechanism to determine is the challenge was signed by the correct user on the correct device.
segment.target: In an actual implementation you would need to implement a verification mechanism to determine is the challenge was signed by the correct user on the correct device.

segment.source: Add the method below to the MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs
segment.target: Add the method below to the MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs

segment.source: In the MicrosoftPassportHelper class call the RequestSignAsync method from the GetPassportAuthenticationMessageAsync method.
segment.target: In the MicrosoftPassportHelper class call the RequestSignAsync method from the GetPassportAuthenticationMessageAsync method.

segment.source: Throughout this exercise, you have updated the client side application to use the AuthService.
segment.target: Throughout this exercise, you have updated the client side application to use the AuthService.

segment.source: By doing this you have been able to eliminate the need for the Account class and the AccountHelper class.
segment.target: By doing this you have been able to eliminate the need for the Account class and the AccountHelper class.

segment.source: Delete the Account class, the Models folder, and the AccountHelper class in the Utils folder.
segment.target: Delete the Account class, the Models folder, and the AccountHelper class in the Utils folder.

segment.source: You will need to remove all reference to the Models namespace throughout the application before the solution will successfully build.
segment.target: You will need to remove all reference to the Models namespace throughout the application before the solution will successfully build.

segment.source: Build and run the application and enjoy using Microsoft Passport with the mock service and database.
segment.target: Build and run the application and enjoy using Microsoft Passport with the mock service and database.

segment.source: In this hands on lab you have learned how to use the Passport APIs to replace the need for passwords when using authenticate from a Windows 10 machine.
segment.target: In this hands on lab you have learned how to use the Passport APIs to replace the need for passwords when using authenticate from a Windows 10 machine.

segment.source: When you consider how much energy is expended by people maintaining passwords and supporting lost passwords in existing systems, you should see the benefit of moving to this new Microsoft Passport system of authentication.
segment.target: When you consider how much energy is expended by people maintaining passwords and supporting lost passwords in existing systems, you should see the benefit of moving to this new Microsoft Passport system of authentication.

segment.source: We have left as an exercise for you the details of how you will implement the authentication on the service and server side.
segment.target: We have left as an exercise for you the details of how you will implement the authentication on the service and server side.

segment.source: It is expected that most of you will have existing systems that will need to be migrated to start working with Microsoft Passport and the details of each system will differ.
segment.target: It is expected that most of you will have existing systems that will need to be migrated to start working with Microsoft Passport and the details of each system will differ.
